items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are now falling steadily on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook.
Flooding is forecast to continue to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the road at Reybridge.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout Tuesday however it is not predicted to create further flood risk even when the rivers rise slightly from the additional rain.
River levels are continuing to fall steadily tomorrow morning on 24/01/2024 but may increase slightly during tomorrow afternoon on 24/01/24.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message:
Derwent Water lake level remains high due to recent heavy rainfall. Further rain is expected today. Levels may steadily fall throughout the morning but may start to rise again this afternoon and throughout the evening.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwent Water lake level, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site .

We are continuing to monitoring rainfall and lake levels at the Lodore gauge and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water.  Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is expected today Tuesday 23/01/23. Lake levels are likely to rise this afternoon and into the evening.  The levels are expected to remain high throughout the next few days. 

Flooding is affecting locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. 

We are continuing to monitor river and lake levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are beginning to fall at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of Storm Isha. However due to more rain we expect further rises. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 23/01/24. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 4.1m to 4.5m overnight tonight 23/01/24, Cae Howel peaking now at 3.95m 23/01/24. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high in the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on 23/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely through today, Tuesday 23rd January 2024.  This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system.  We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.   We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Wednesday 24th January 2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently falling at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Upper Og Valley following winter rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Levels are currently falling but levels at this site are sensitive to individual rainfall events and will likely rise again following rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 26/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.58m and rising in response to rainfall over the weekend. The Huish Episcopi drain level is 7.67m and falling steadily as pumping operations continue. Flooding will affect the road between Muchelney and Langport if this drain level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Thorney road above 7.93m, and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.80m. No property flooding is expected at this time. Refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closure information.

We are pumping at Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations, and are using the Parrett Relief Channel to reduce levels as much as possible. There is more rain forecast tonight and showers tomorrow. We continue to maximise pumping operations to clear as much water off the moors as possible. We are monitoring this situation closely.

Please do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water, and be careful using footpaths near local watercourses and flooded areas. This message will be updated by 2 PM on 23/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hambledon remain very high. The level at Whitedale Farm peaked on Monday 15/01/2024, and has since fallen by 8cm. Currently, we expect that most cellars on East Street are dry, and the need for cellar pumping on East and West Street has reduced. Fareham Road is flooded, and the sewerage system will be impacted by groundwater. The football pitch is being affected by a mixture of groundwater and sewerage. Dry weather is forecast until Friday 19/01/2024. However, the weather is expected to become more unsettled over the weekend, with up to 10mm of rain expected across Saturday 20/01/2024 and Sunday 21/01/2024. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling, but they will remain sensitive to further heavy rainfall. If heavy rainfall affects Hambledon over the coming weeks, then groundwater levels could reach those recorded in February 2014. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and are monitoring the forecast. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 24/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels remain very high. In the Chalton Lavant, flows are reducing after 2 weeks of dry weather. Flow in the Idsworth Lavant remains high. We expect a small number of cellars to be affected. Roads in all villages will be affected by water and groundwater will be impacting the sewerage network. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy driving conditions. Today (18/01/2024) and Friday (19/01/2024) are forecast to be dry. From Saturday 20/01/2024 to Monday 22/01/2024, unsettled weather is expected to return with up to 15mm of rain expected during these three days. Groundwater levels are expected to remain high but impacts are expected to continue improving. However, levels will be sensitive to heavy or prolonged rainfall this winter. More widespread impacts to cellars and roads, as well as surface water flooding is possible after the next heavy rainfall event. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 25/01/2024.

items.description: Mansbridge and Riverside Park
items.message: Flows in the Lower River Itchen at Mansbridge remain high. Only small amounts of rain have been recorded in the last 24 hours. High tide in Southampton today (23/01/2024) at 21:50, is forecast at 4.23 metres Chart Datum (1.49 mAOD). Tomorrow morning’s tide (24/01/2024) at 10:00, is forecast at 4.08 metres Chart Datum (1.34 mAOD). For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the incoming tide will prevent the river from flowing to sea. This may cause the river to flood the access road and affect the car park near to the White Swan Pub at Mansbridge. Footpath flooding may also affect Riverside Park. Further rainfall (up to 10mm) is forecast for today (23/01/2024). We will monitor the forecast and have opened the sea door at Woodmill. We recommend closing the defence gates around the pub at least an hour before high tide. This Flood Alert will be updated by 14:00 on 24/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high in response to winter rainfall across the area. Levels are high but have currently stabilised at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater.

The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels and levels will likely rise again following rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 26/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: This alert remains in place as levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain and the River Hull. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is expected on Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 23/01/2024. Areas most at risk include the River Hull area around Arram, Tickton, Beverley and Dunswell. Our pumping stations are operating to reduce levels, however water levels will remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are falling at the Lilbourne river gauge. However, further rainfall is expected in the next 12 hours as a result of Storm Jocelyn where river levels have been forecast to rise today at 17:00. Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible this afternoon into tomorrow morning, 24th January 2024. Flooding will affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.

We expect river levels to rise this afternoon and remain high overnight into Wednesday, 24th January 2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 24th January 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Leadon catchment
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Frome in Herefordshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen again on the Upper Wey in response to last night's rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore possible today 23/01/24, especially in the Godalming area. The forecast is for showers throughout the day until the late evening. Tomorrow 24/01/24 is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high, and to be responsive to further rainfall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Tees and estuarine tributaries

floodArea.county: County Durham, Darlington, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire, Stockton-on-Tees

items.message:
River levels on the Lower River Tees and estuarine tributaries are falling from Storm Isha as rainfall eases. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. 

Further rainfall is forecast today, 23/01/2024 as a result of Storm Jocelyn. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Flood Gates at Yarm, Croft and Neasham will remain closed in anticipation of the forecast rainfall from Storm Jocelyn.  

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: This Flood Alert for the North Sea Coast from Bridlington to Barmston has been issued due to the risk of wave overtopping on Tuesday 23/01/2024 between 12:00 PM and 6:00 PM. Areas most at risk include Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion, and South Pier and the Lifeboat Station at Bridlington. Wave action will also be a hazard. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.
River levels are high on the River Windrush following rainfall at the start of the month. Water is expected to remain in and on low lying land and roads over the next few days particularly near the confluence with the River Thames. A band of rain is forecast to cross the area today, Tuesday, it may be heavy at times but will be fast moving reducing the total rain in any one place. Wednesday is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days although they are not expected to rise much in response to todays rainfall. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: This alert remains in place as whilst river levels are falling, they remain high on the River Foulness and Market Weighton Catchment. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is expected across Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 24/01/2024. Flooding is expected to affect locations near Mill Beck in Market Weighton, on Market Weighton Canal, Ings Beck in North Newbald, North Cave Beck in North Cave and the River Foulness near Welham Bridge, with low lying land expected to be most affected. We continue to monitor river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rede
items.message:
River levels on the River Rede are falling from Storm Isha as rainfall eases. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow, 23/01/2024 as a result of Storm Jocelyn. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: This warning remains in place as river levels in the upper River Hull catchment remain high following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is expected across Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 24/01/2024. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill, including Roam Drain. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action and avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high, very close to the surface, but slowly falling. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water will also affect the B2141 Chilgrove road. Rainfall is forecast early Sunday morning, again Sunday evening, and Tuesday 23/01/2024. Groundwater in the Chilgrove borehole will likely continue falling this week, although the decline will slow. In the East Dean borehole groundwater could rise a few centimetres this week. Less rain is forecast for the start of February. However, groundwater will remain very close to the surface in communities, and flood impacts could continue through to March. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 24/01/2024.

items.description: Upper River Aire catchment
items.message:
River levels are continuing to drop across the catchment following the overnight rain associated with Storm Isha. Areas most at risk include the River Aire from Gargrave to Stockbridge, including Eshton Beck, Eller Beck and Silsden Beck.

Further rainfall is forecast today, 23/01/2024 as Storm Jocelyn arrives. This rainfall will see levels start to rise again and the washlands start to fill this afternoon. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 21:30 on 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on Brough Beck and the River Swale in response to rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Areas most affected are low-lying land, particularly around the River Swale and its tributaries from Catterick Bridge to the confluence with the River Ure.  Further rainfall is forecast on Tuesday and Wednesday associated with Storm Jocelyn which means that river levels are likely to rise again. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ure due to rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Areas most affected are locations near the River Skell, and River Ure, particularly low-lying land including agricultural land and local roads, in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton. Further rainfall is forecast on Tuesday and Wednesday associated with Storm Jocelyn which means that river levels are likely to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wiske and other tributaries of the River Swale, with low-lying land expected to be most affected. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is forecast on Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 24/01/2024 which will keep levels high. We continue to monitor the situation closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Nidd catchment
items.message: This alert has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Lower River Nidd catchment
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Nidd at Skip Bridge and Hunsingore due to rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Areas most at risk include low lying land around the lower River Nidd from Hunsingore down to Skip Bridge and its tributaries, including Sand Beck, Sike Beck, Pool Beck and Great Gutter. Further rainfall is forecast on Tuesday and Wednesday associated with Storm Jocelyn which means that river levels are likely to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. items.description: River Ure at Boroughbridge Camping and Caravanning Site
items.message: This warning has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels across the West of Dorset have continued to drop back, but remain well above normal. Some minor flooding of roads remains possible and septic tanks may not function effectively over the coming days. Rainfall expected over the early part of next week is not expected to lead to a significant increase in the risk of flooding. Environment Agency staff will continue to monitor the situation. This Flood Alert will remain in force for the next few days at least and will be updated should the forecast change.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: River levels are steadily rising on the River Ouse due to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Flooding is expected at properties along Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place, St George's Field carpark and Rowntree Park. River levels in York are expected to peak on the morning of Tuesday 23/01/24. Further rainfall is forecast on the upper catchments over the coming days. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at Naburn Lock
items.message: River levels are continuing to rise steadily on the river Ouse due to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the river Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas throughout the day. Further rainfall is forecast on the upper catchments over the coming days. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wylye and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Wylye due to rainfall over the weekend.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wylye, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Norton Ferris and Wilton.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Norton Ferris and Wilton from 9:30 AM on 23/01/2024.
Further rainfall is forecast this morning.
River levels will rise steadily at the Brixton Deverill, Norton Bavant, South Newton gauge.
Our incident response staff are checking defences and trash screens.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in Wilton.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Further property flooding is not expected.

River levels are high on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. Water is expected to remain in and on low lying land and roads over the next few days. A band of rain is forecast to cross the area today, Tuesday, it may be heavy at times but will be fast moving reducing the total rain in any one place. Wednesday is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Please report any blockages to the Environment Agency. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen again on the Lower River Loddon in response to last night's rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore possible today 23/01/24, especially in the Sindlesham Mill area. The forecast is for scattered showers throughout the day until the late evening. Tomorrow 24/01/24 is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high, and to be responsive to further rainfall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high, close to the surface, but slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will likely continue, with springs affecting fields, rural roads including Stoughton main road and the road from East Marden. Groundwater will affect a small number of properties close to the village green, Stoughton. Groundwater will also be close to the surface, in basements and near the ground floor of properties in Walderton. Rainfall is forecast early Sunday morning, again Sunday evening, and on Tuesday 23/01/2024. Groundwater will probably continue to fall over the week ahead, although at a slower rate. Less rain is forecast for the start of February. However, groundwater will remain close to the surface in communities, and minor flood impacts could continue through to mid February. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 24/01/2024.

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.

River levels are high and out of banks along the Lower River Kennet following recent rainfall. River Levels rose overnight in response to Sundays rainfall, they have now stabilised and we expect to see them start to slowly lower through the day. Water is expected to remain in and on low lying land and roads over the next few days. A band of rain is forecast to cross the area today, Tuesday, it may be heavy at times but will be fast moving reducing the total rain in any one place. Wednesday is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Wharfe
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Wharfe downstream of Tadcaster as a result of recent rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Areas most at risk include the Tidal River Wharfe downstream of Tadcaster, with low lying land expected to be most affected. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is forecast on Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 24/01/2024 which will keep levels high. Plan driving routes to avoid roads between Tadcaster and Cawood that are affected by flooding. We will continue to monitor river levels. This message will be updated by 9pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Wharfe

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Wharfe, Kel Beck, Town Beck, Collingham Beck, Fir Green Beck, Bramham Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Wharfe due to rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Areas affected are locations near the River Wharfe, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the lower River Wharfe and tributaries from Otley to upstream of Ulleskelf. Further rainfall is forecast on Tuesday and Wednesday associated with Storm Jocelyn which means that river levels are likely to rise again. Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through floodwater. Consider putting your flood plan into action. We are continuing to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Patcham
items.message: Groundwater is high, close to the surface, but slowly falling at the Ladies Mile borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue to affect a small number of basements on Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. Rainfall is forecast early Sunday morning, again Sunday evening, and on Tuesday 23/01/2024. Groundwater will remain close to the surface and minor flood impacts could continue through to February. Groundwater will probably continue to fall over the week ahead, although at a slower rate. It is possible groundwater might rise slightly by midweek, near Old London Road, Patcham. Less rain is currently predicted for the start of February, which could allow flood impacts to reduce further. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 24/01/2024.

items.description: Lower River Eden
Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: Groundwater levels across Cranborne Chase have continued to drop back, but remain well above normal. Some minor flooding of roads remains possible and septic tanks may not function effectively over the coming days. Rainfall expected over the early part of next week is not expected to lead to a significant increase in the risk of flooding. Environment Agency staff will continue to monitor the situation. This Flood Alert will remain in force for the next few days at least and will be updated should the forecast change.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Bourne at Tidworth Manor Bridge and Salisbury Bourne river gauges due to groundwater. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock. There is some rainfall forecast in the next week which may cause water levels to rise. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover remain very high, but are stabilising in most villages. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden, Penton Grafton, and Penton Mewsey. Groundwater is affecting Deacon and Down Road in Kimpton, the main road in Penton Grafton, and the road from Biddesden to Appleshaw. Inundation of the sewerage system is expected to be occurring in most villages. Surface water flood risk is ongoing in Thruxton. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy conditions. The weather until Friday 19/01/2024 is expected to be dry. More unsettled weather is forecast on Saturday 20/01/2024 with up to 11mm of rain expected in Hampshire. Groundwater levels remain sensitive to rainfall. If heavy rain affects the area, ongoing flooding impacts will increase, and internal property flooding at Hatherden could occur before the end of January 2024. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 23/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and continue to slowly rise. Since Tuesday 09/01/2024, the level in Hursley has risen by 22cm. We expect widespread cellar flooding to be occurring in the village, and some properties are likely to be affected by internal property flooding. Groundwater is affecting the sewerage system. The weather until Friday 19/01/2024 is expected to be dry. More unsettled weather is forecast on Saturday 20/01/2024, with up to 11mm of rain expected in Hampshire. Groundwater levels are expected to stabilise in the next few days, but if heavy rain affects Hursley, groundwater levels and ongoing flooding impacts will increase. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 23/01/2024.

items.description: River Wye in Herefordshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. However due to more rain we expect river levels to fall & then rise again.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine &Hereford. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 2.18m 22/01/24, Bredwardine peaked at 3.97m 22/01/24, Belmont peaked at 3.97m 22/01/24,  Old Wye Bridge peaked at 3.55m 22/01/24, Mordiford peaked at 3.79m 22/01/24 & Ross on Wye peaked at 3.22m this morning 23/01/24.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 5pm on 23/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of Storm Isha. However due to more rain we expect river levels to fall and then rise again.
Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Peaks:- Ross on Wye peaked at 3.22m this morning Tuesday 23/01/24 and Lydbrook peaked at 3.91m this morning Tuesday 23/01/24.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 5pm on Tuesday 23/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Meon Valley are high, but continue to slowly fall. At Pound Lane in Meonstoke, levels are falling by 8cm per day. In Meonstoke, groundwater levels are high in the lower part of the High Street. There may be some residual water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy driving conditions. Dry weather is forecast until Friday 19/01/2024. However, the weather is forecast to become more unsettled over the weekend, with up to 10mm of rain forecast across Saturday 20/01/2024 and Sunday 21/01/2024. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling, but will remain sensitive to heavy or prolonged rainfall this winter. Cellar flooding impacts in West Meon could occur after the next heavy rainfall event due to a combination of high river flows and groundwater levels. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remain prepared for further impacts this winter. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 24/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels across Salisbury Plain have continued to drop back, but remain well above normal. Some minor flooding of roads remains possible and septic tanks may not function effectively over the coming days. Rainfall expected over the early part of next week is not expected to lead to a significant increase in the risk of flooding. Environment Agency staff will continue to monitor the situation. This Flood Alert will remain in force for the next few days at least and will be updated should the forecast change.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: Groundwater levels in Twyford and Hensting remain very high but are now stabilising. We expect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting to be affected by cellar flooding. There is water on the road in Hensting Lane. The spring on Finch’s Lane is issuing, and the Bourne is flowing in the ditch on Hazeley Road. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy driving conditions. Dry weather is forecast until Friday 19/01/2024. However, the weather is forecast to become unsettled over the weekend, with up to 10mm of rain expected across Saturday 20/01/2024 and Sunday 21/01/2024. Groundwater levels are expected to begin falling in the next few days but will remain sensitive to heavy or prolonged rainfall this winter. If heavy rainfall occurs in the area in the next couple of weeks, then a larger number of properties in Twyford could be impacted by cellar flooding, and sewerage network issues could occur. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 24/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: In the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels remain very high but have now stabilised. We expect ongoing cellar flooding at Upton, Hurstbourne Tarrant, Stoke, Vernham Dean and St Mary Bourne. Isolated properties in the valley may be experiencing internal flooding. The road through Upton will be impassable. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy driving conditions. Groundwater is affecting the sewerage system in all villages. Today (18/01/24) and Friday (19/01/24) are forecast to be dry. From Saturday 20/01/24 to Monday 22/01/24, unsettled weather is expected to return with up to 15mm of rain expected during these three days. Groundwater levels could begin to fall over the next few days, but they will remain sensitive to further heavy rainfall recorded this winter. If very heavy rain is recorded in the coming weeks, groundwater levels could be similar to those recorded in 2014. We have deployed temporary barriers at St Mary Bourne to help manage flood risk. Please ensure any pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 25/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bramdean and Cheriton remain very high but are now relatively stable due to the recent dry weather. Isolated properties in Cheriton will be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively in both villages. Dry weather is forecast until Friday 19/01/2024. However, the weather is forecast to become more unsettled over the weekend, with up to 10mm of rain forecast across Saturday 20/01/2024 and Sunday 21/01/2024. Groundwater levels are expected to begin falling in the next few days, but will remain sensitive to heavy or prolonged rainfall this winter. If heavy rain is recorded in the next couple of weeks, cellar flooding in Bramdean is possible. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 24/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: Groundwater levels in East Kent have risen following recent higher than average rainfall and are expected to remain high until Spring 2024. The Alkham Bourne and the Nailbourne between Lyminge and Littlebourne are flowing. Flows in the Little Stour between Littlebourne and Stourmouth have increased over the past month. Localised flooding may affect low-lying land, roads, and water infrastructure in and around the Elham Valley, Alkham, and Petham. Other communities in East Kent may also be impacted. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. The forecast is largely dry until Sunday 21st before potentially turning unsettled again next week. We are monitoring the situation and are working with local authorities and communities with the deployment of temporary defences, such as Canterbury City Council’s temporary defences in Barham. Our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. This message will be updated by Thursday 25 January 2024, or as the situation changes. Search ‘Kent Groundwater Situation’ on gov.uk.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message: Groundwater levels in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne are high, but relatively stable following the recent dry weather. We expect cellar flooding will be affecting a small number of properties in Little Somborne, and properties along Winchester Road, Old Vicarage Lane and the A3057 in Kings Somborne. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy conditions. The weather until Friday 19/01/2024 is expected to be dry. More unsettled weather is forecast on Saturday 20/01/2024 with up to 11mm of rain expected in Hampshire. Groundwater levels remain sensitive to rainfall. If heavy rain affects the area in the next couple of weeks, property flooding and sewerage system impacts in Kings Somborne could be possible in late January or February. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 23/01/2024.

items.description: Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.description: Rivers Caldew and Petteril
Middle River Eden
Rivers Lowther and Eamont
items.message:
River and lake levels are remaining high on the Rivers Lowther and Eamont due to recent rainfall. Today Tuesday 23/01/23 we have a further band of rain with Storm Jocelyn that will cause these levels to rise again throughout the afternoon and evening.

Flooding is possible at Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby.

We are continuing to monitor river and lake levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Esk and Irthing
Gypsey Race and the Wolds

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This alert remains in place as river levels remain high on the Gypsey Race due to rainfall and high groundwater levels. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is expected across Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 24/01/2024. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Gypsey Race, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Gypsey Race from Wold Newton to Bridlington. Groundwater will remain high for some time. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Eden at Carlisle, Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses
River Eden at Low Crosby, Warwick Holmes
River Swale at Howe village and by Skipton Bridge
items.message: This warning has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary.

items.description: River Wiske at Kirby Wiske
items.message: River levels remain high but are gradually decreasing on the River Wiske due to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Isha. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wiske, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties in Kirby Wiske. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is forecast on Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 24/01/2024 which will keep levels high. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, groundwater levels remain very high. In the last 24 hours, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 2cm. We expect a small number of properties in Preston Candover and Old Alresford will be pumping water out of their cellars. In Old Alresford, the level is stable, close to where we expect 1 property to be experiencing internal flooding. Groundwater levels will reduce the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. Today (18/01/2024) and Friday (19/01/2024) are forecast to be dry. From Saturday 20/01/2024 to Monday 22/01/2024 unsettled weather is expected to return with up to 15mm of rain expected during these three days. Groundwater levels will remain high throughout January 2024 and will be sensitive to further heavy rainfall this winter. Some properties in Preston Candover may experience internal ground floor flooding if further heavy rain is recorded in the coming weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 25/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bishops Sutton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bishops Sutton remain high and stable following the recent dry weather. Impacts to septic tanks and flooding of roads such as the B3047 is expected. A small number of properties in Bishops Sutton may have a very small amount of water affecting their cellars. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy conditions. The weather until Friday 19/01/2024 is expected to be dry. More unsettled weather is forecast on Saturday 20/01/2024 with up to 11mm of rain expected in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects Bishops Sutton, cellar flooding impacts will increase, and internal property flooding could occur in late January or February. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 23/01/2024.

items.description: Roam Drain and River Hull at Hempholme
items.message: This warning remains in place as levels remain very high on Roam Drain following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Further rainfall associated with Storm Jocelyn is expected across Tuesday 23/01/2024 and Wednesday 24/01/2024. Areas most at risk include properties in Hempholme and around Hunt Hill Farm. River levels have now peaked but are expected to remain high and flooding of properties will continue for some days. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to closely monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Tuesday 23/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 

River levels are high on the River Kennet following recent rainfall. Water is expected to remain in and on low lying land and roads over the next few days especially around Knighton. A band of rain is forecast to cross the area today, Tuesday, it may be heavy at times but will be fast moving reducing the total rain in any one place. Wednesday is expected to be dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message:
The groundwater level at the Clarendon borehole has now peaked and will continue to slowly drop back over the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties is expected to gradually recede throughout the week.
Residents should keep any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers deployed as there may be a delayed response.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may remain problematic over the next few days.
Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Friday 26th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm near Great Shefford in response to the winter rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. Groundwater levels are currently steady, but could rise further if we see persistent or heavy rain. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 26/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Burn from Southgate and Waterden to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because of the continued flood risk to homes and businesses today, Monday 22nd January. River levels remain higher than normal in response to rainfall earlier this month.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas in South Creake and Burnham Thorpe, including parts of the B1355. We expect the river level to remain steady. The forecast is for a dry day today, Monday 22nd January, and showers tomorrow, Tuesday 23rd January. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Tuesday 23rd January.

items.description: River Pang at Bucklebury
items.message:
Property flooding is no longer expected.

River levels increased on the River Pang as a result of overnight rainfall Sunday, combined with raised groundwater levels. Levels have been slowly droping through the day. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold, however river levels are sensitive to further rainfall.  
No rain is expected overnight but we are expecting further rain on Tuesday. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.

items.description: River Lambourn from Upper Lambourn to Great Shefford
items.message:
Property flooding is possible. 

River levels on the River Lambourn are high following Sunday's rainfall and high groundwater levels. Further flooding of property is possible but not expected and flooding of roads and low lying land will continue today. Tuesday, especially in the Eastbury area. A band of rain is forecast to cross the area today, Tuesday, it may be heavy at times but will be fast moving reducing the total rain in any one place. River levels will remain high over the coming days, but they are not expected to rise much in response to todays rainfall. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water and be aware of flooded roads, do not drive through floodwater. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is expected.

Flood warnings are currently in force for the Upper and Lower River Lambourn. 
River levels are high as a result high groundwater levels and rain on Sunday. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads and property is expected to continue today, 23/01/2024, especially in the Shaw area. A band of rain is forecast to cross the area today, Tuesday, heavy at times but will be fast moving reducing the rain totals. Wednesday is expected to be dry. River levels will remain high over the coming days, they are not expected to rise much in response to todays rainfall. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bourne Rivulet
items.message: The water level in the Bourne Rivulet at St Mary Bourne is high and rising steadily. In the last 24 hours 17mm of rainfall has been recorded at Andover. This follows months of prolonged and wet weather. The river is currently bankfull. River levels will be impeded by bridges upstream of St Mary Bourne and rainfall events will cause surface water flooding in Upton. Extensive field and road flooding through the Bourne Valley is expected. Over the next 5 days, the weather remains unsettled, with further rain forecast (up to 12mm) on Tuesday (23/01/2024). The river may rise and fall throughout this time, and generally, levels will remain much higher than normal. The river will remain elevated and sensitive to any further rainfall over the next few weeks. Flood barriers are now deployed to help to reduce the risk of flooding in St Mary Bourne. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on 24/01/2024.

items.description: Nailbourne and Little Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message: River levels remain high on the Little Stour and Nailbourne. The risk of flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to remain into the start of the week. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along the River Nailbourne around Bekesbourne, and areas along the Little Stour around Littlebourne. Flooding of property is not currently expected. Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater. Further rain is expected Sunday evening into Monday and with continuing unsettled conditions this may cause river levels to respond. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated by 6pm on Tuesday 23 January 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Burn from South Creake to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because of the continued flood risk to homes and businesses today, Monday 22nd January. River levels remain higher than normal in response to rainfall earlier this month.  Areas most at risk are North Creake, South Creake and Burnham Thorpe including the B1355. We expect the river level to remain steady. The forecast is for a dry day today, Monday 22nd January, and showers tomorrow, Tuesday 23rd January. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Tuesday 23rd January.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: In Deane and Ashe, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since Wednesday (10/01/2024), the groundwater level at Oakley has risen by 90cm. The River Test is flowing upstream of Ashe. Groundwater spring flows are impacting land and the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. We expect that properties in Deane will be affected by cellar flooding. The access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) may need to be closed from this weekend. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy conditions. The weather until Friday 19/01/2024 is expected to be dry. More unsettled weather is forecast from Saturday 20/01/2024 with up to 11mm of rain expected in Hampshire. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising for most of January 2024, and will rise for longer if heavy rain affects the area. Increased flooding impacts are expected over the coming weeks. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 23/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high. At Lopcombe Corner, levels are falling by around 20cm per day. In Pitton, we expect water to be affecting the main road, impacting on the sewerage system, and a small number of properties in the High Street and Townsend to be affected by groundwater. We expect that property in Nether Wallop, and land and gardens in Over Wallop will be impacted. At West Tytherley, groundwater levels are rising by around 7cm per day. Cellar, land and road flooding in central West Tytherley, as well as impacts to septic tanks, are imminent. Unsettled weather is expected on Tuesday (23/01/2024) and on Thursday (25/01/2024), although rainfall totals in Hampshire are expected to be relatively small. Groundwater levels at Lopcombe Corner are expected to continue falling. Impacts in Pitton, Nether Wallop, Over Wallop and Broughton should improve. At West Tytherley, levels are forecast to peak later this week. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 29/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Littleton, Headbourne, Kings and Martyr Worthy, Easton and Chilland
items.message: At Harestock, groundwater levels are high, but are now falling by 15cm per day. In Martyr Worthy, Chilland and Easton, drainage ditches and culverts will be full. Some properties may be experiencing some internal flood impacts as water seeps up through the floors. Footpaths near to the river are expected to be inaccessible. In Kings Worthy, Headbourne Worthy and Littleton, residual water may still be affecting cellars, the sewerage network and roads, but flood impacts will be decreasing. Water on roads may freeze and cause icy conditions. Dry weather is expected until Friday 19/01/2024. Unsettled weather is forecast on Saturday 20/01/2024 with up to 11mm expected in Hampshire. Groundwater levels will continue to fall, but if heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels and flood impacts will increase again, potentially bringing similar or worse impacts to those seen in the last couple of weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 23/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high and are slowly rising due to winter rainfall across the area as we can see at our Hodcott observation borehole near West Ilsley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 26/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn from Donnington to Newbury
items.message:
Further property flooding is possible.

River levels in the River Lambourn are high following Sunday's rainfall and high groundwater levels, however they have been stable and slowly dropping overnight. Flooding of properties is still possible and flooding of roads and gardens is expected, especially in areas close to the River Lambourn in Newbury. Areas most at risk are Donnington, Shaw and areas around the confluence with the River Kennet. A band of rain is forecast to cross the area today, Tuesday, it may be heavy at times but will be fast moving reducing the total rain in any one place. River levels will remain high over the coming days, they are not expected to rise much in response to todays rainfall. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Be aware of flooded roads; do not drive or walk through floodwater. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 24/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Newmarket
items.message: Groundwater levels are rising slowly in response to prolonged wet weather. Flooding is possible. This message applies to areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 11am Wednesday 24 January, and then on a weekly basis.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the upper Avon valley and the Nine Mile river
items.message:
The groundwater level at the Everleigh borehole has now peaked and will continue to slowly drop back over the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties is expected to gradually recede by the beginning of next week.
Residents should keep any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers deployed as there may be a delayed response.
Driving through flood water will be especially dangerous as temperatures will drop to below freezing at times over the next week and will cause ice to form on roads. The bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties and lead to icing of pavements.
Sewage systems may remain problematic over the next few days.
Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated on Saturday 13th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Alton area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall across the area and have risen above the level that requires early awareness at the Farringdon observation borehole. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year, and have currently stabilised at this high level. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall, due to saturated ground and levels may start to increase again as we receive further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 30/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Aldbourne Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the Winter rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole at Water Acre in the Aldbourne Valley. The level is currently steady. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the next few weeks and levels remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 26/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Eden at Warwick Bridge, Holme House, Bridge End and Holme Eden Hall
River Ure at Masham
items.message: This warning has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary.

items.description: River Eden between Newby East and Low Crosby
River Tweed South Bank
items.message:
River levels on the River Tweed at Norham are falling from Storm Isha as rainfall eases. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. 

Further rainfall is forecast today, 23/01/2024 as a result of Storm Jocelyn. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Eden and Caldew at Carlisle, Devonshire Walk, West Coast Mainline, Bitts Park, Cricket Club
Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few weeks by flooding from groundwater.

Groundwater levels in this area are geerally stable but we expect to see them rise if we recieve further rainfall over the next few weeks. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message later this week on the 26/01/2024, or as the situation changes.
